The spring it is coming on fast,</br>The birds they are percht on the sprays,</br>The wintery frosts they are past,</br>The shepherds are tuning their lays.
The trees are cover'd with leaves,</br>The ground it is cheerfully green,</br>But still the lost Corydon grieves,</br>For Phillis is not to be seen.
The daisey is raising its head,</br>The golden-cups cover the ground;</br>See my heards on the meadow are spread,</br>See my flocks they are feeding around.
But my heards they no longer delight,</br>Nor my flocks can give pleasure to me;</br>For say, is the daisey so white?</br>Or the golden-cup brighter than she?
My mind it is tortur'd with doubt,</br>My breast is tormented with fear;</br>Like a madman I run all about,</br>And I ramble I do not know where.
I sleep not a wink all the night,</br>And my days they do dolefully pass;</br>'Till I see her (oh!  exquisite sight!)</br>Come tripping it over the grass.
Oh!  say, can'st thou hear me complain,</br>Nor list to thy shepherd so true?</br>Oh!  come, and give life to the swain</br>Who now is a dying for you.
No hurt, my sweet Phillis shall ail,</br>By Venus the goddess I vow;</br>For whilst I am holding the pail,</br>Why — she shall be milking her cow.</br>
